persona.name: James Wilson
persona.expectation:
Lectures should start early 19thcentury There should be few tangents. Lectures should include some of the following:
  • Adams v Jefferson
  • Peaceful transfer of power
  • Andrew Jackson
  • Lincoln
  • 1896

iterations.name: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

content.name: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860
content.description: Examines how Lincoln's 1860 victory led to Southern secession and the American Civil War.
content.introduction: The election of 1860 stands as a significant moment in American history, marking the immediate catalyst for the secession of Southern states and the onset of the Civil War. Tensions over slavery had been mounting for decades, with compromises and political maneuvering failing to reconcile the deep divides.

sections.name: Antebellum Tensions
sections.body: Prior to the 1860 election, the United States grappled with increasing sectionalism. The Missouri Compromise and the Compromise of 1850 attempted to balance free and slave states, but the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 and the Dred Scott decision in 1857 heightened tensions.

sections.name: Political Fragmentation
sections.body: The Democratic Party split into Northern and Southern factions, with John C. Breckinridge representing the South, and Stephen A. Douglas the North. Meanwhile, the Constitutional Union Party emerged, hoping to avoid secession over the slavery issue.

sections.name: The Republican Platform
sections.body: The Republican Party, with Abraham Lincoln as its candidate, advocated for halting the expansion of slavery. They did not call for its outright abolition, but their platform was seen as a threat to the Southern way of life.

sections.name: Election Day
sections.body: On November 6, 1860, Abraham Lincoln won the presidency with a majority of electoral votes, despite receiving less than 40% of the popular vote. His victory was achieved without any Southern electoral votes.

sections.name: Secession Begins
sections.body: South Carolina reacted to Lincoln's election by seceding from the Union on December 20, 1860. This act set off a chain reaction, with Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas following suit.

sections.name: The Confederate States of America
sections.body: The seceded states formed the Confederate States of America in February 1861, drafting their own Constitution and electing Jefferson Davis as President, firmly establishing their break from the Union.

sections.name: The Fort Sumter Crisis
sections.body: Lincoln's inauguration on March 4, 1861, did not ease tensions. The standoff at Fort Sumter in South Carolina became the flashpoint that led to the outbreak of the Civil War on April 12, 1861.

content.conclusion: The election of 1860 was a culmination of years of sectional discord over the issue of slavery and served as the immediate cause for Southern secession and the Civil War. The impact of this election reverberated through the subsequent conflict and the reconstruction that followed.

children.name: Secession Winter: The Deep South Leaves the Union
children.description: Analyzes the rapid secession of Southern states following Lincoln's election victory.

children.name: The Formation of the Confederacy
children.description: Explores the creation of the Confederate States of America and its constitution.

children.name: Fort Sumter and the Outbreak of War
children.description: Details the events at Fort Sumter that led to the first battle of the American Civil War.

children.name: Lincoln's Early Presidency and the Union's Response
children.description: Discusses Lincoln's initial actions as president and the Union's military and political strategies.

tangents.name: The Cooper Union Address
tangents.description: Lincoln's speech at Cooper Union helped to elevate his national profile and political stance against slavery's expansion.

tangents.name: The Dred Scott Decision
tangents.description: The Supreme Court ruling that denied citizenship for African Americans and the federal government's power to regulate slavery.

tangents.name: John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry
tangents.description: John Brown's attempt to initiate an armed slave revolt by raiding the federal arsenal at Harpers Ferry.

iterations.prompt:
LECTURE: You are to create a lecture called "The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" Your lecture has a description in the course offering that reads: "Exploring how Lincoln's election ignited secession and the Civil War, reflecting deep national divisions over slavery." Your lecture should be about 1000 words long and have 5 to 10 sections. If possible, your lecture should reflect the following topics: Presidential Elections.
 You will create a lecture in the way described below. You will format your responses in JSON as described below. 

 BEFORE YOU BEGIN... You have a golden rule: Do not use the words "transformative", "pivotal", "iconic" or "crucial" in your lectures. If you do, I WILL PET A CAT BACKWARDS AGAINST THE NATURAL DIRECTION OF ITS FUR AND THE CAT WILL BE PERTURBED. 

 ---------------------------------------------------
 
 IF THE LECTURE TOPIC IS TOO BROAD, DO THIS:
  
  - The lecture must not be to big or general. For example, if asked about the History of the United States tell the user that is too broad.  When this happens, offer a JSON-formatted list of lectures related to the initial lecture idea that are more specific and narrow. Here is an example of the answer for these cases:

    {
        "type": "too_broad",
        "children": [
            {
                "name": "<Event name here/>",
                "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
                "description": "<30-word description of the event and why its importantance/>",
                  "type": "event",
                  "score: 1,
            },
            ...
        ]
    }

 ---------------------------------------------------

  IF THE EVENT IS NOT TOO BROAD DO THIS:          
  
  
  FIRST: Come up with 1 to 3 themes that capture the essence of the event and why it is important. THEN create the lecture around those themes.

   

  
  Your answer should be JSON-formatted and include the following:

  1) Name: A concise name for the event that captures the themes you came up with.

  2) Description: Short, roughly 30-word descrption of the event and it's importance. 
  
  3) Introduction: A 50-word introduction to the event explaining its historical significance. After that, an 50-word summary of what lead up to the event. If there are previous lectures, your wording sould transition soothly from the previous lecture.

  4) Dates: A JSON array with the time span of the event in the form of two dates. Do not put the dates in the summary. 

  5) Sections: The lecture should be broken down into between 5 and 10 sections. These should walk the user through the event in detail and in chronological order.

  6) Conclusion: A JSON-formatted conclusion that breifly summarizes the event and introduces the event's down-stream effects that you listed.

  7) Children: Create 3 or 4 follow-up history lectures that would be good follow-up lectures to "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860". Try to stay close to the event in time, and don't go more than 10 years into the future.
    - Each lecture should have a relevance_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".
    - Each lecture should have a insterestingness_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".

  8) Tangents: Come up with 3 or 4 historic events that took place around the same time as "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" that is not directly related to "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" but is related to "\Presidential Elections".
    - The tangent should have a insterestingness_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".

  9) Themes: 2 to 3 themes that capture the essence and importance of the main event. These should no more that 2 words.

  10) Topics: 2 to 3 topics that are part of the main event. These should no more that 2 words.

  11) Wikipedia page: Come up with a list of Wikipedia pages that would help test the accuracy of your lecture on "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860". These are to be pages and not full URLS
  
  Below is an example of the JSON formatting I want. Be sure to escape quotes that are inside of strings. 
  ALSO, IF YOU DO NOT RETURN PROPERLY FORMATED JSON, A BABY EWOK WILL BE EUTHENIZED!!! Here is what I want:
  
  {
    "type": "event",
    "name": "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860",
    "description": "Summary of event goes here.",
    "introduction": "100-word introduction goes here.",
    "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD}, 
    "sections": [
        {
            "name": <Name of the section/>,
            "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
            "body": <A 100-word body of the secion/>,.
            "type": "section"
        }
        ...
    ],
    "conclusion": "Conclusion goes here.",
    "children": [
        { 
          "name": <Name of the lecture/>, 
          "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
          "description: <Brief 30-word description of the lecture/>,
          "type": <Effect or broad perspective/>,
          "relevance_score": <relevance_score/>,
          "interest_score": <interest_score/>,
        }
        ...
    ],
    "tangents": [{
        "name": <Name of the tangent/>,
        "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
        "description: <Brief 30-word description of the tangent/>,
        "type": <Tangent/>,
        "relevance_score": 0,
        "interest_score": <interest_score/>,
      },
      ...
    ],
    "themes": [<Theme/>, ...],
    "topics": [<Topic/>, ...],
    "wikipedia_pages": [<Wikipedia page/>, ...]
  }

fact_eval.reason: The submitted answer is a subset of the expert answer and is fully consistent with it. The submitted answer provides an accurate, though less detailed, summary of the events leading up to and following the election of 1860, the candidates involved, and the immediate outcomes in terms of Southern secession and the Civil War. It does not conflict with the expert answer but omits many of the specifics and nuances that the expert answer includes, such as the detailed breakdown of the conventions, the full scope of the election results, and the specific dynamics within each party.

New lecture: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

Lecture summary: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

Examines how Lincoln's 1860 victory led to Southern secession and the American Civil War.

Prior to the 1860 election, the United States grappled with increasing sectionalism. The Missouri Compromise and the Compromise of 1850 attempted to balance free and slave states, but the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 and the Dred Scott decision in 1857 heightened tensions. The Democratic Party split into Northern and Southern factions, with John C. Breckinridge representing the South, and Stephen A. Douglas the North. Meanwhile, the Constitutional Union Party emerged, hoping to avoid secession over the slavery issue. The Republican Party, with Abraham Lincoln as its candidate, advocated for halting the expansion of slavery. They did not call for its outright abolition, but their platform was seen as a threat to the Southern way of life. On November 6, 1860, Abraham Lincoln won the presidency with a majority of electoral votes, despite receiving less than 40% of the popular vote. His victory was achieved without any Southern electoral votes. South Carolina reacted to Lincoln's election by seceding from the Union on December 20, 1860. This act set off a chain reaction, with Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas following suit. The seceded states formed the Confederate States of America in February 1861, drafting their own Constitution and electing Jefferson Davis as President, firmly establishing their break from the Union. Lincoln's inauguration on March 4, 1861, did not ease tensions. The standoff at Fort Sumter in South Carolina became the flashpoint that led to the outbreak of the Civil War on April 12, 1861.

The election of 1860 was a culmination of years of sectional discord over the issue of slavery and served as the immediate cause for Southern secession and the Civil War. The impact of this election reverberated through the subsequent conflict and the reconstruction that followed.
